clues.text: A reliable person is "as honest as the day is" this
In a time-worn simile this adjective precedes "as a fiddle"
An exceptionally clumsy person is like "a bull in" one of these establishments
You don't have to sew to be "as neat as" one of these objects used by seamstresses
Something that turns out well "comes up smelling like" these flowers
One of these celestial beings appears on Arkansas' seal along with an eagle & liberty
The frigate Raleigh, built in Portsmouth in 1776, adorns this state seal
One can see the Snake River & a man plowing among the items on this state seal
Because he once had a colony in Newfoundland, George Calvert put the fisherman on this state seal
Its seal shows a map of the state & the surrounding states of Mississippi, Florida, Georgia & Tennessee
In 1979 Dan White was found guilty of killing George Moscone, this city's mayor
After 300 years of British rule this West Indies island chain gained its independence in 1973
In 1978 John Paul I died, only a month after succeeding this pope
Head of the FBI in 1978, he became CIA director in 1987
In January 1972, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman became the prime minister of this newly independent nation
His vice presidential running mates were John Nance Garner, Henry Wallace & Harry Truman
Nuclear weapons development is the responsibility of this department, not Defense
James Thompson, who left office in January 1991, was this state's governor for 14 years, longer than anyone
From 1975-1980 she served as Connecticut's first woman governor
This Cabinet department publishes many periodicals, including the Consumer Price Index
Bernini was asked to draw plans for this French museum, but jealous French artists sabotaged it
From the Italian "grotta", "cave", it originally described overly ornate decor as in Nero's Golden House
Tintoretto painted this biblical meal for the church of San Giorgio Maggiore
Antonio Canova's nude model of this emperor is in the Wellington Museum in London
His "Calumny of Apelles" & "Birth of Venus" are in the Uffizi
In her freshman year at college this TV talk show host was named Miss Black Nashville & Miss Black Tennessee
Missouri's only national monument marks the birthplace of this famous scientist
He was ABC's senior Capitol Hill correspondent before becoming chief Washington anchor for CNN
A sculpture of this seamstress & civil rights heroine was unveiled recently at the Smithsonian
She died in Paris in 1975 during the 50th anniversary celebration  of her Paris debut
O'Connell Street is this European capital's main boulevard
Now Ecuador's capital, in 1487 it became the northern capital of the Inca Empire
The Rashtrapati Bhavan, or presidential house, in this capital, has 340 rooms
This city's most important avenue, Rasheed Street, parallels the Tigris River
This capital city lies on the Red River in the Tonkin Delta
Shortly before Edith died this show changed its name to "Archie Bunker's Place"
Eve Arden was honored by the National Education Association for her role as a teacher on this sitcom
The Jeffersons moved on up to Manhattan's East Side after George made a fortune in this business
Edward Mulhare was the hauntingly handsome Captain Daniel Gregg on this series
Before making it big in the movies Tom Hanks starred in this TV sitcom
The red stalks of this vegetable are popularly used in sauces & in strawberry pie
The French call this part of the chicken, "pilon", for its resemblance to a pestle
The name of this thick Creole soup comes from an African word for okra
From the French for "with scrapings", it's the brown crust of butter & bread crumbs, or grated cheese
This sweet red syrup made from pomegranates is used to add color & flavor to a cocktail
William could tell you this informal name for a small wooden club
Called the first form of ammunition, there was even an age named for them
In 1936, Hermann GÃ¶ring said these "will make you powerful, butter will only make us fat"
A maliciously destructive critique or a bit of business for Carrie Nation
The U.S. Army pays $1.8 million for each M1 Abrams, which is this, & $3,300 for decoy copies
Pete Townshend said he smashed these instruments because, "I like them"
He planned his Ring Cycle to be a tragedy of the most shattering effectiveness
When flautist James Galway tried this instrument, he said, "It was like trying to blow an octopus"
Igor Stravinsky called it "semaphoring"
This composer's last words were said to be these poignant ones, "I shall hear in heaven"
This Rhode Islander painted portraits of our first six presidents
This flamboyant Confederate who wore plumed hats was only 31 when he was mortally wounded in 1864
He retired from auto racing in 1973 after his teammate Francois Cevert was killed
He was married to actress Jean Simmons when he starred in "The Prisoner of Zenda" in 1952
In 1964 this associate justice defined obscenity as "I know it when I see it"

rounds.text: Muzak has b'cast words twice, for simulcast of "We Are The World" & announcement of this 1/20/81 event
rounds.response: the release of the Iran hostages
